content.title: First Post
content.body:
Was your first week what you expected? Why? Why not?

The first week wasn't too surprising for me. Meeting on the first day was interesting, it was strange to be in a classroom or school-like environment with much older students (including me) than the last time I was in school.

What are you struggling with?

Well, for the this assignment in particular I managed to tunnel on one slide and forget to check the others for assignments. I have also missed a standup purely due to my own negligence. These types of logistical struggles are common for me, so I will just need to stay on full alert for the duration of the prework. Once the in-person work begins, I expect to have less problems in that area.

What are you excited or eager to learn more about?

I'm excited to get more into javascript, node, react, etc. The logical elements behind webpages are way more interesting to me than the visual ones.

content.title: Week Two Questions
content.body:
What are your thoughts on Pseudo Coding?

I enjoyed writing the pseudocode. The line between pseudocode and actual code was not clear to me - something like a for loop seemed like a specific feature of specific languages, so I wasn't sure if that was something I could use in pseudocode.

What are you struggling with?

I am not struggling with anything, particularly.

What are you excited or eager to learn more about?

I'm still excited about getting into javascript, and server-side web development.

content.title: Week Three Questions
content.body:
What are your thoughts about the roles HTML, CSS, and Javascript play in the process of rendering content and providing user experience?

Hmm, that reads an awful lot like a test question... The answer that you're probably looking for is that HTML provides the structure for a web page, CSS makes it readable for humans, and Javascript makes it interactive.

content.title: Week Four Questions
content.body:
What was one thing you liked and disliked about each of the new topics covered in Prework?

I'm not too sure which topics you're referring to, but if its HTML/CSS/Javascript:
I liked understanding more of the interaction between HTML and CSS. I still don't like the actual design process, involving adding css and then visually checking the page, changing the css again, etc.
I really enjoyed working with javascript. Writing code that's simple and does the job is extremely satisfying. I didn't dislike anything about it. Though I am told that once I learn other languages I will have things to complain about with javascript.

What was helpful?

Justin and Ian were quite helpful! When I asked a question on slack, they responded within the minute.

What hindered your progress?

I can't think of anything external that really hindered me. Wow classic, perhaps.

How did you overcome challenges?

Blind persistence.

content.title: Week Five Questions
content.body:
What did you learn about that helped you understand more about Design?

The talk on CRAP design principles was enlightening. One of my takeaways was the importance of whitespace.

What do you want to continue learning about that helps you understand Design better?

Learning and talking about graphic design was fun, but I would love to learn more about design in general, not just specifically graphic design.

What Design aspects are important to you as a user and as a developer?

I appreciate the concepts of Design that were talked about this week for how practical they were - they really took into account the actual purpose of what's being designed. I guess the most critical aspect of design to me is to keep the main thing the main thing.
